definitions.definition: To clean (a surface) by means of a stroking motion of a broom or brush.
definitions.example: to sweep a floor, the street, or a chimney

definitions.definition: To move through a (horizontal) arc or similar long stroke.
definitions.example: The offended countess swept out of the ballroom.

definitions.definition: To search (a place) methodically.
To travel quickly.
To play a sweep shot.
To brush the ice in front of a moving stone, causing it to travel farther and to curl less.
To move something in a long sweeping motion, as a broom.
To win (a series) without drawing or losing any of the games in that series.
To defeat (a team) in a series without drawing or losing any of the games in that series.
To remove something abruptly and thoroughly.
definitions.example: She swept the peelings off the table onto the floor.

definitions.definition: To brush against or over; to rub lightly along.
definitions.example: Their long descending train, / With rubies edg'd and sapphires, swept the plain.

definitions.definition: To carry with a long, swinging, or dragging motion; hence, to carry in a stately or proud fashion.
To strike with a long stroke.
To row with one oar to either the port or starboard side.
To draw or drag something over.
definitions.example: to sweep the bottom of a river with a net

definitions.definition: To pass over, or traverse, with the eye or with an instrument of observation.
definitions.example: to sweep the heavens with a telescope

definitions.definition: (including) to vacuum a carpet or rug
An instance of sweeping.
definitions.example: The sidewalk needed a sweeping every morning.

definitions.definition: The activity of sweeping.
Wide, broad, affecting or touching upon many things
definitions.example: He loves making sweeping statements without the slightest evidence.

definitions.definition: Completely overwhelming
